text: hi this is SEMA and I'm back with a new
lesson on question tags well we all know
what a question is so if I said are you
happy it's a question are you hungry
a very good question but what is a
question tag well a question tag is
nothing but the words that come after a
question or after a sentence that makes
you agree with a particular question so
let's look at a sentence with a question
tag so we have che is tired isn't she in
this case isn't she becomes my question
tag now the simple question is why do
you need to use a question tag well let
me tell you a question tag is used in
formal and in informal speech so that
you can get someone to agree with you
when you say something okay so you want
to get someone to agree with you and a
question tag is almost a confirmation or
gives us an emphasis on what we are
actually trying to prove so it is a
confirmation or an emphasis of the point
you make and that is why we use a
question tag now since we use question
tags as I said while speaking it is very
important to know the quality of my
voice the pitch of my voice and the tone
of my voice
and that is what intonation is all about
and that is where intonation comes in
intonation is nothing but the rise and
the fall in my voice the rise and fall
in the tone of my voice in the pitch of
my voice so when I had a rising
intonation my voice kind of you know
just goes higher the pitch of my voice
the tone of my voice increases and when
I indulge in what I call as the falling
intonation I kind of just come down a
little bit okay
well let's see why and when do we use
the rising intonation and why and when
would I use the falling intonation well
ah it's pretty simple okay the rising

I would say that was a good movie wasn't

well my wasn't in kind of you know just

now I will deal with how to structure a
question tag which is something you also
need to know along with using the
intonation
as I said it is also important to know
how to form or how to structure a
question tag well there are two main
rules and the first one is to know that
if your main verb in the sentence is a
positive one the question tag at the end
of your sentence will always be negative
and vice versa which means if my main
verb is negative the question tag at the
end of the sentence will automatically
be positive so let's look at the main
verb in the sentence which is he is
funny so the main verb what is it is
your main verb in the sentence and is is
the the verb off is the form of to be
the to be verb so it is one of the forms
of the to be verb so since is is
positive the negative form is isn't also

you have the negative form which is is
not and my rule states that since my
main verb is positive my question tag
will be a negative one so the is gets
converted to n is not and the the
pronoun which is he falls after the Li
is not or the negative form of the verb
so I will say he is funny and then I
look at I take a quick look at the main
verb change that into the negative and
then add the hey at the end of the
question and that's that makes the
question tag we have now something like
she didn't finish her homework
did she well you've got two verbs your
but the main verb is did which is the
form of the verb
to do okay and did not is negative
didn't means did not but the rule states
that if the main verb is negative then
my tag will be positive and vice versa
which means the did not gets converted

not and then I add the pronoun after the

and then I take a quick look at the main

I put the pronoun at the end of it with
the question of course well let's move
on to our next point when determining as

rule says that question tags which are
formed with a do or a don't or a did or
a dint they are really used when the
verbs do not come with auxiliaries or
when the the verb is without an auxilary
for example um you have a sentence like
she didn't finish her homework I did

we've got actually two words in this

which supports the other the main verb

like they speak English fluently now if
